title: What will happen if I do a transfusion putting liquid beet with only blood nutrients + nutrients and other things that blood has but beet doesn't in a rat? Does it work? Can I test it in my home with a rat? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you were to transfuse beet juice, it wouldn’t matter what else was in that beet juice. That individual would die. Plain and simple, that individual would die. There’s really no such thing as “blood nutrients” because blood doesn’t manufacture nutrients. It’s not an organ and is, itself, manufactured — the cells originate from red bone marrow and plasma is derived primarily from water & salts absorbed through the GI tract. I don’t need to address in detail the immunoglobulins, enzymes and other proteins in plasma. Blood doesn’t create these. Blood is made up of plasma, cells and cell fragments (platelets, which we also call thrombocytes). Blood transports nutrients in varying proportions & amounts at any given time. What do you know about starting IVs? Have you taken at least a 2-day course? Are you certified? Do you really think you could find a viable vein on a rat? And you have a rat-size IV starter kit?? But don’t bother because you would kill the rat and I’m not sure why you haven’t given any thought as to how beet juice is supposed to function like blood unless that’s because you don’t understand the functions of blood in the first place. Hey, not being judgmental, just being honest.

Why on earth use beet? What’s the rationale of that—just because beet juice is red? The red color of blood is from the hemoglobin contained in the red blood cells. Hemoglobin is needed to transport oxygen in the blood. All sorts of horrible things could result from replacing blood with beet juice; among them, if you replaced enough of the blood, the animal would quickly die of oxygen starvation. Blood nutrients would be irrelevant. Trying this at home would be difficult to begin with because you probably don’t have enough skill to correctly place an IV line in an animal and know what volumes can be safely transfused and at what rates. Even a nurse or phlebotomist with advanced training on how to do this on human patients probably couldn’t do it on a rat. But secondly, if one got past that hurdle, its cruel effect on the rat would be surpassed only by the stupidity of the person who tried this. If I knew of someone doing this, I’d report him to the authorities for animal cruelty.
